summary:
I'm an international development professional with a deep interest in leveraging information and communication technologies to address development challenges in a variety of contexts. My current work centers on improving patient-centered care through the use of digital adherence technologies and supporting national tuberculosis program systems to deliver quality healthcare to low-resource environments while collecting reliable, timely data for improved decision-making. In my spare time I am particularly interested in the use of UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles) for transportation of health supplies and lab samples in logistically-challenged areas.

Past and ongoing interests range from building technologies to bridge the gap between paper-based and digital data, improving supply chain practices through global collaboration, the opportunity of ICTs to enable social and economic inclusion of Persons with Disabilities, and researching the impact of interactive technologies to improve maternal and child health during labor.

projects.title: MIT D-Lab International Development Design Summit (IDDS)
projects.description:
	Analyzed logistical challenges in polio vaccine campaigns in Pakistan and worked with frontline health workers to co-design, prototype, and test a mobile solution to improve efficiency of monthly immunization activities. 
	Worked with international group of 28 individuals from 15 countries to leverage ICT solutions to address challenges in health, agriculture, and social entrepreneurship as part of highly-selective (14% acceptance rate) workshop funded by the International Development Innovation Network (IDIN) at MIT’s D-Lab.

projects.title: Researching Accelerator Revenue Models to Increase Internal Funding: The Unreasonable Institute
projects.description: This project addresses the lack of internally-generated revenue at the Unreasonable Institute (a social and environmental entrepreneur accelerator in Boulder) by examining a variety of accelerator programs across the spectrum and identify practices and business strategies that increase revenue. Our final deliverable report briefly covers current revenue-creating practices and strategies of 14 different accelerators and more presents recommendations to the Unreasonable Institute of how to create an additional $50,000 annually in internally generated revenue. Our recommendations combine more common revenue builders such as alumni programs and corporate sponsorship with more creative strategies, such as entrepreneur speaker gigs and book deals.

contributors.headline: Looking for non-profit opportunities in the Bozeman area
My work is driven by a deep consideration for designing technologies that address cultural and gender-based inequities.

projects.title: Interactive Arduino: Things That Think
projects.description: The Things That Think team designed two interactive Arduino microprocessor projects intended to synthesize modern information technology with more traditional art and craft materials. The Artemis and Apollo project utilized photosensors and motorized gear systems along with 3D printed objects and wood materials to create a moving, interactive dancing automoton that responds to light input. The History of Electricity project used Nitinol muscle wire, (shape metal alloy) LEDs, conductive paint, 3D printed objects and conventional craft materials to create a 3-scene interactive diorama. Both projects utilized the Arduino microprocessor system and custom code to exemplify how new computer technology can be paired with traditional materials to create new ideas of art, education, and interdisciplinary design.

projects.title: Musoni Microfinance in Kenya
projects.description:
Musoni BV is the first cash-free microfinance social enterprise in the world.

The MS-ICTD ATLAS Team designed, prototyped and deployed a Learning Management System for Musoni BV that supports digital testing and e-learning automating the training and assessment time of HR and making data analysis much more possible and effective.

profile_positions.title: Digital Health Consultant

profile_positions.description:
Integrating technology design, assessment, and implementation for global health systems projects in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).

Drones for Health
• Coordinator and founding member of UAV for Payload Delivery Working Group (UPDWG), bringing together 100+ stakeholders in global health, drone manufacturing, humanitarian funding, academia, and ministries of health to evaluate the opportunity for UAVs to improve health services delivery at the last mile.
• Led business development efforts to test UAV technology, assess supply chain models, and develop use cases around UAV delivery of vaccines, lab samples, and essential medicines.

Global OpenLMIS Project 
• Designed functional requirements and user needs for OpenLMIS, an open standard, enterprise-level electronic logistics management information system (LMIS) aimed at improving vaccine and essential medicine supply chains in LMICs. Worked with development teams to build, test, document, and implement software.
• Led coordination of global, multi-stakeholder meetings to understand needs, determine  integrations, and promote joint ownership in the project. Led organization of regional user design workshop in West Africa, convening ministry-level health officials from Benin, DRC, Cote d’Ivoire, Guinea, and Senegal to co-prototype appropriate interface design for the system.
• Conducted on-the-ground research on electronic health systems in LMICs, analyzing potential points of integration to support global data standardization efforts. Includes work with partners in Zambia, Tanzania, Ethiopia, and Pakistan.

ODK Scan (an Open Data Kit project)
• Managed collaboration with University of Washington computer science department in development of app, including refinement of machine-reading classifiers, improving number recognition accuracy, and creating custom data reports. 
• Led pilot implementations in Malawi and Pakistan to improve data collection on maternal health and TB-DOTS, respectively.
profile_positions.title: Technology Associate

profile_positions.description:
I. Global Consultation on ICTs, Disability and Development:
Supported project design, data collection, data analysis (quantitative and qualitative), and report synthesis of the Global Consultation on ICTs, Disability, and Development, a multi-stakeholder consultation advocating the key role that ICTs can play in an inclusive post-2015 development agenda. Lead editor and contributing writer for the resulting report, “The ICT Opportunity for a Disability-Inclusive Development Framework,” produced specifically as input for the UN High-Level Meeting on Disability and Development. Link to report. Produced collaborative briefings, background documents, and fundraising analysis to support development of ITU strategy in the area of ICT accessibility. 

II. BYND 2015: Global Youth Summit:
Defined and coordinated program activities for BYND 2015, a three-day global youth summit in Costa Rica to gather opinions of international youth and explore the role of ICTs in addressing key global challenges, including themes in entrepreneurship, environment, health, safety, and global governance. Recruited potential speakers and determined their most effective roles, briefing speakers and delegates on the content and themes of the Summit. Liaised with ITU member states, sector members, private companies, NGOs, and academic institutions to coordinate delegate activities and logistics. Managed Summit activities on-site in Costa Rica.
profile_positions.title: Junior Policy Analyst, Corporate Strategy Division

profile_positions.description: Assisted with pilot implementation of a maternal health development project based in Nairobi, Kenya. Debuted the use of specially-programmed digital pens in a labor ward setting to reduce mother and infant mortality during childbirth and to facilitate better usage of existing global health tools. Trained 40+ nurses on pen functionalities and cultivated collaboration between researchers, nurses, and administrators. Provided essential feedback to the head researcher, designed handoff schedule/parameters, and managed the team budget.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant - PartoPen Marternal Health Project

profile_positions.description: Organized grant submissions and program activities for an environmental and urban development philanthropic fund focused on leveraging partnerships for policy and community development. Processed grant proposals, assisted in program evaluation and review, and prepared recommendations for Board of Trustees. Wrote all articles and edited layout for the newsletter. Organized and traveled to off-site meetings, conferences, and grantee site visits. Compiled daily news briefings for staff, managed MFF social networking sites, and distributed internal memos to officers, members, and potential future members.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Program and Grants Management Officer

profile_positions.description: Coached technique and fitness, managed equipment acquisition and use, and planned and budgeted regatta travel outings. Fostered a community of professionalism as the club sport transitioned to Div. II varsity status. Ran sweep rowing practice for UML students under direction of head coach.
